pull.title: Don't wrap around when deriving an extended key at a too large depth
pull.body:
We would previously  silently wrap the derived child's depth back toÂ `0`. Instead, explicitly fail when trying to derive an impossible depth, and handle the error in callers.

An extended fuzzing corpus of `descriptor_parse` triggered this behaviour, which was reported by MarcoFalke.

Fixes #25751.

verification.payload:
tree 7da4f5693a3406a12667faa060a1f3795dd63ee1
parent 6d8707b21d3a5b4abb76b773a69f2bfac22bcd93
author Antoine Poinsot <darosior@protonmail.com> 1658223712 +0200
committer Antoine Poinsot <darosior@protonmail.com> 1658225615 +0200

spkman: don't ignore the return value when deriving an extended key

events.message: spkman: don't ignore the return value when deriving an extended key

events.body:
Is the wrap actually harmful?

In any case, current code will never do this, right?

It is harmful in the sense that this behaviour is not specified by BIP32. We could accept an invalid descriptor or xpub that another software would refuse (or worse, treat differently).

> In any case, current code will never do this, right?

Well, it *was* triggered by current code.

verification.payload:

descriptor: never ignore the return value when deriving an extended key

In some cases we asserted it succeeded, in others we were just ignoring it

extended keys: fail to derive too large depth instead of wrapping around

This issue was reported to me by Marco Falke, and found with the
descriptor_parse fuzz target.

events.message:
extended keys: fail to derive too large depth instead of wrapping around

This issue was reported to me by Marco Falke, and found with the
descriptor_parse fuzz target.

events.body:
Hadn't occurred to me this implicit limit due to the encoding of xpub/xprv.

utACK  https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/25642/commits/fb9faffae3a26b8aed8b671864ba679747163019

comments.body: Maybe mark as `[[nodiscard]]` in the header?
Done, and fixed two missing occurrences (in the descriptor tests) this revealed. Thanks!
